column1: How many Chevrolet Bolt EV's will be sold between January and June 2018?
column6: ['Technology']
column11: Chevrolet's new electric vehicle, the Chevrolet Bolt EV, is being rolled out country wide in the fall of 2017 (The Green Car Report). Outcome will be determined by the 2018 total listed for Chevrolet Bolt EV on the InsideEV website (InsideEV) after the June 2018 data has been released. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: 6,775 sold with only 1 month left to go. https://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/

Excerpts from Inside EV's May report. "It has been an interesting year for electric vehicle sales with a lackluster January, the longest reporting holdup ever in February, and a record-breaking March. April also landed in the five-spot for all-time EV sales, which brings us to May. May easily secured a spot in the top five early on." You would think the rising tide of EV sales would positively impact the Bolt, but if the estimated sales numbers are to be believed, it has not.
They'd need a record month to hit 10k, and that's not the recent trend.

GM has publicly stated that it will no longer release monthly sales results for the U.S. Instead, the automaker will move to a quarterly release schedule - so the April number from Inside EV's is an estimate. So my estimate is based on another estimate - this just feels wonky! GM needs to sell 2,200 Bolt EV's a month for the next two months to get over 10,000. This looks less and less likely to happen (even though they averaged over 2,600 per month the last half of 2017. The Bolt EV still qualifies for government incentives, including up to $7,500 in Federal income tax credits and (select) state rebates. There have been Increases in gas prices over the last several months while competitor TESLA is unable to meet production goals. and yet the April sales estimate fell by 28% compared to last month. The April 2018 seasonality factor is less than 1 and finance rates on 5-year consumer loans from banks for new cars are up from just over 4% to close to 5% over the last 6 months. This may be contributing to the estimated slowdown in sales. Irrespective of the reasons why and barring another oil embargo, I now feel confident that less than 10,000 Chevrolet Bolt EV's will be sold between January and June 2018.

Meh. Some time ago I made a long post about how GM production line was 2500 per month, and how last year they had a huge inventory to move out, so they made incentives. This year they didn't have the inventory back log; they had ceased all financing options.

5650 sold and 2/3 through forecasting period. Some latency in reporting? Cooler Spring? Thought there’d be more uptake given Tesla 3. Regardless, lowering forecast despite Bolt getting decent reviews etc

Looking at the published February sales numbers my initial forecast was too high. Again without the benefit of much historical data, this is going to be a tough forecast. The expected bump in sales from Consumer Reports giving the Bolt top marks and Motor Trend bestowing Bolt with the EV of the Year award was smaller than I expected. While the increase in sales from January was a solid 21 percent, given January, February, November, and December look to be the slowest sales months based on their Federal Reserve seasonal factor numbers, I've revised my forecast down. With the benefit of two more data points (Jan & Feb sales data), the expected growth in units demanded based on the 6 month moving average of units sold dropped by over 4 percent - likely reflecting the winter doldrums. This reduced the expected total number sold to about $14,300. Anything can happen between now and June from a massive recall to a large spike in gas prices which is a reason for the "shotgun approach" to the probabilities. (Another is the mean absolute % error being so big.) Let's see if my new improved calculations hold up when the actual March sales numberis releasd in Early April. Stay tuned!

The US has not really woken up on this issue yet and there is still space for several players in the market. The mass production potential of GM is formidable, however, the Bolt cannot satisfy a market for an upper-end, quality vehicle. Nonetheless, the Bolt may appeal to many average consumers who are ready to take the plunge. Also, I would consider the not so obvious agents of change such as Uber drivers, delivery drivers who use their own vehicles. When the US wakes up and realizes that the short-haul market is ripe for savings in fuel, things may start to change. One of the principle drivers will be the availability of charging stations. GM could use its influence to promote charging station growth which would float the entire industry. Tesla has taken the lead with its network of Superchargers​.

This is a challenging estimate due to the lack of historical data, the Chevy Bolt was introduced in December 2016. In a nutshell, I took the monthly sales data and deseasonalized it using 'Federal Reserve Seasonal Factors for Motor Vehicle Sales'. I then took a 5-month moving average of the sales figures and ran some simple formulas to solve for units of demand and deviation from that demand. Applying a growth formula for the remaining 5 months 'til June 2018 (January's sales #'s are already available) and backed out the seasonal factors or "reseasonalized" (totally made that up) and totaled the estimates. The probability estimates are normal distribution percentages one and two standard deviations from the mean. I will revisit this each month and revise and refine my forecast along the way.

January: 1177 sales. Total sales in Jan-June last year around 7500. Looking at the data from the Volt, we should expect around 40% of sales being made in the first half of the year. Also, the last three months of the year seem to usually account for more than third of the yearly sales. Projecting the 9000 sold units from the last three months of 2017 (when the model was available nationwide) upwards, we get an expected amount of a bit above 27000. This yields around 11000 sales in the relevant time frame, with a tendency to slightly understimate. However, the data from january looks comparable to last year, indicating, that the model might be too optimistic.

Range is still the deciding factor. Once EV ranges exceed 500 miles and with quick charging or interchangeable charged batteries are available, the vehicles will take off in the market. A major limitation is that manufacturers are NOT designing interchangeable charging stations or swappable batteries and until this happens, EVs will be restricted to commuter cars. EV sales in the US for all manufacturers will not exceed 250,000 per year until after 2020.

When it became clear there was a pretty good chance the $7500 federal tax credit would be lost, I cut my projection and have let this slide since then. With the November sales figures out, I've taken another look at the numbers:

Sales have been steadily increasing lately now that the Bolt is on sale nationwide. My guess is that they stay around 3K per month through the first quarter of 2018, with high upside risk. Based on strong media reports, weak Tesla performance, and demand so far, looks like low downside risk for the Bolt in the first half of 2018.
November sales were more than I expected. So the numbers for the second half of this year are: 1971 (July) + 2107 (Aug) + 2631 (Sept) + 2781 (Oct) + 2987 (Nov) + 4050 (Dec estimate) = 16,527.

Elements I thought about: This isn't normally distributed. There are greater odds for less than 10,000 because of a recall, or other large event resulting in short-term slowdown. On the supply side it seems difficult for more than 25,000 to be sold in 6 months (per @cmeinel) The rest of the forecast is based on me thinking that a value around 18-19k is in line with growth, with decent potential for the various factors (tax-credit, macro economics, large corporate/government purchase agreement) driving it higher or lower. Answers I'd like to know: What is the historic seasonality of auto sales? Do any large states have EV policies (rebates for cars or charging stations) taking place on January 1, 2018?

Bolts are available in all states by September. 2017 January through June, they were only available from 7 to 18 states, though these included NY and CA. Number sold for January-June 2017 was 7592. Sales numbers pick up in later months of the year. August 2017 number is 2107.

Initial forecast/reactions. As other posters have mentioned, with Bolt EV's upward trend and very positive 2017 YTD results, I don't see a large chance of Chevy selling < 10k units in 1H2018. However, as more units hit the roads, there is still a likelihood that there are unforeseen issues with the cars (structural issues, battery fires, issues with autonomous driving) that would cause sales to drop off.
News about the Bolt autonomous vehicle with Cruise Automation may provide a ceiling for purchases now, since the AV will need more accessories and hardware.

For those looking for models, I would offer the Chevrolet Volt, a hybrid introduced in December of 2010. The first six months of 2012 sales increased over the first six month of 2011 sales by 221%. The Honda Fit, introduced in 2006, increased sales by 102% in 2007. (I could only find annual figures as opposed to month to month.)
Headlines: Sales Jan. through Aug. 2017: 11,670. Aug. sales: 2,052. There now are currently 1235 Bolt EV–certified stores in the United States, ~40% of the 3000 U.S. Chevy outlets.

No change in the forecast since this analysis isn't exactly news, but Motley Fool did a pretty good analysis suggesting that Chevy may see 2,500 per month as successful, which would put the 6-month total at around 15,000.
Shifting down a little as the jump from July to August was less than I hoped.

Just taking Jul-Aug purchases and extrapolating to 6 months would put the number at 12,234. 1971 sales in Jul, 2107 sales in Aug. Since Jul/Aug typically make up 17-18% of total year, and Jan-Jun 48-50%, (https://www.edmunds.com/industry-center/data/sales.html and http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2012/10/usa-auto-industry-total-sales-figures.html) that would put estimated 2018 Jan-Jun sales at 11,327. Depending on whether you extrapolate from July, Aug, or the two combined, and how you estimate those months share of total sales, the estimates will vary between 10,500 and 13,000. Fleets will be wary, since the charging infrastructure may not be there to start and drivers may not trust it. Probably fleets won't buy much in 2018, so I wouldn't expect that to change the overall sales numbers much. Looks like they won't advertise very broadly (http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1111082_yes-ads-for-the-chevy-bolt-ev-electric-car-do-actually-exist-heres-one), so I wouldn't expect a big push from that.
Even odds the Bolt tops the "InsideEV" US sales table by the end of 2017?

Batteries to replaced on a few hundred (less than 1%) Bolt EVs due to 1 bad cell (out of 288 cells). http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1112295_2017-chevy-bolt-ev-battery-may-fail-due-to-faulty-cell-new-pack-needed-for-a-few-of-gms-electric-car
The sales should at least remain at the level of 2017, should achieve 10K as US EV market is maturing.
The general interest among populations for green technology and due to the success of Tesla.

My guess is that EV cars are only getting more popular, albeit slowly. Since Chevy sold just under 10,000 Bolts in the first half of this year that seems like a good baseline. Their customer will be dramatically bigger in the first half of next year (going from 18 to all states) so I think we see a increase, even though those first 18 states were probably the biggest markets for EV vehicles. Furthermore, sales have been steadily increasing, even in the face of added competition. I think next year we see similar slow but steady growth.
Chevy as a brand is fading, Tesla is hot, and oil prices will stay low.

If GM only produces 25-30k in 2018, then wouldn't this constrain sales to roughly 12-15k per six month period as high side? Am I missing something obvious? US historic sales show rise, but current best month extrapolated to first six months next year result in less than 10k, which seems to make under 10k more likely than I believe most are considering. Looking at competitive sales, 10-15k seems most likely.

Hybrids still outsell full EV. GM is staking a position, not intending mass sales. Low gas prices, improving technology, few charging stations, impending driverless cars, Tesla mark 3, all are depressing sales. Will outsell Leaf but not Tesla.
Adjusting forecast on the basis of data and analysis provided by @redsparrow at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/554023 Thank you!
As of the end of June, US sales totaled 6529.

Demand: They are selling at a 37k$ price before federal tax credit(GM is taking a loss on this) => 30k$ after credit which is lower than the average car price in US, hence don't think demand should not be an issue. As awareness increases, demand should go up steadily.
